bboxes.raw_text:
Nathaniel Robins on, 2S4o West
Jefferson ST., has received Nat
ional Science Foundation grant.
He received one two years ago.
also.


Mr.. Robinson will attend the
summer session at the University
of Missouri. at Columbia. He will
study geology.


A teacher at Julian School in the
Roosevelt District for the past
thirteen years. MIR. Robinson
holds bachelors degree from
Langston University and mas
ter's degree from ASU.


He is the schools science
coordinator and Is special events
chairman for the second time for
the Roosevelt Classroom Teach
ers Assn.

Salt River Power District will
contribute nearly SIS million to
the county treasury in lieu of 1864
taxes.


The county's share will total
nearly 100000, county manager
Joseph Herrick said. The same
amount will 60 to the state and
the balance will be divided among
towns in the county using Salt
River facilities, the county junior
college district and various
school districts.


First half of the lieu tax pay
ment will be made in November,
the balance is due in May of
next year.

CANNES. France--"One Po-
tato Two Potato" a movie deal
ing with the marriage of white
and Negro in the United States
won an award at the annual French
film festival.


The picture which was ignored
by the Hollywood selection COM
mittee won an ovation.


Director Larry Peerce said
the picture costs S250,000. 1t
tells how white divorcee loses
legal custody of her young daugh-
ter after marrying Negro fac
tory worker.

The Rev. Martin Luther King,
Jr.. will appear in the Valley for
the first time ate GOODWIN Stadium,
AS.U. Tempe, on June 8, 8 pm.
His appearance is sponsored by
the National Association for the
Advancement of Colored People
and of leaders of church groups.


Named as Time Magazine
"Man of the Year" for 1868 DR..
King is internationally the known
leader of the non-vlolent civil
rights movement.


Members of religious circles
in Phoenix spoons oring the add
ress are: Rt. Rev. Monsignor
Robert Donohoe, DR.. Kermit
Long, Rabbi Albert l.. Plotkin,
Revs. C. N. Hall, A. G. Ken
dric and Louis Eaton, director
of the Phoenix Council of Chur-
cheS.


Further Information can be
obtained at 212 Greater Arizona
Savings and Loan Building. Phone
252-5296.

NEW YORK Arizona'S lone
representative in the Olympic
boxing trials was eliminated in
the first round Tuesday.


Alton Golfer. Phoenix, was out
pointed by Henry Aaron of At
lanta, Ca, and Fl. Campbell, KY,
in their lightweight bout.


Golfer is a member of the
Russ Keeton Market team of
Phoenix.

A letter from Roy Cooksey,
President of the Southwest Area
Conference of the National Asso-
citation for the Advancement of
Colored People has been mailed
to John E. Evans, secretary
treasurer and executive board
member of the State AFL-C1O.


NAACP urges the State AFL-
Clio executive board to recon-
slider their decision to table the
recommendation of the State
AFL-Cio Civil Rights Commit
tee; that would request funds
from the international union to
be matched by the state to employ
Nn experienced Negro civil rights
field worker.


Cooksey who is also a member
of the State Civil Rights Commit
tee (AFL-CIO) said that the his
tory OF the Negro and organized
labor in Arizona would indicate
that minorities can only be i'm
partially represented by Negro
who is directly associated with
the struggle of minority groups.


Cooksey also stated that unem-
ployment even among unskilled
workers Is much higher than Ne
groes. So since membership
dues have been raised recently
and assessments levied in the
past for less worthy causes the
executive board should not hesi-
tate to give this their immediate
approval.

NAACP Prexy Urges
Union Hiring OF


Negro Rights Workers

CHICAGO = The Chicago Trib-
une said it has learned the War
rem Commission has authorized
an investigation of reports of
heavy drinking by some Secret
Service agents the night before
President Kennedy was assassi-
mated.


The Tribune noted that dis
closure closely followed charges
by Abraham Bolden, a former
member of the White House body
guard detail, that certain agents
drank heavily before and after
their assignments in Dallas.


"a commission member also
told the Tribune that agent Boil
den, first Negro ever assigned
to the presidential protective de-
tail. probably will be called to
testify before the commission"
the story said.


1t quoted the source as saying
it "has always been the COM
missions policy to let anyone
who wants to testify be heard.
Certainly. man who has created
this notoriety and said he wants
to testify. ought to be heard"


Bolden was indicted by fed
eral grand jury on three counts.
charging him with soliciting
through an intermediary
$4,000 payroll for delivery of
secret government file on the
investigation of counterfeting
ring.


Bolden has denied the charges,
saying he was arrested on false
charges in an effort to keep him
from testifying before the War
rem Commission.

Negro Agent Charges


Fake Arrest In Chicago

OKLAHOMA CITY The Unit
ed Presbyterian Church VISA.
elected the first Negro moderator
in its history, the Rev. Elder
G. Hawkins.


The voting commissioners
from 1914 presbyteries gave the
55-year-old New York City min
lister 465-368 margin over the
Rev. Alva Ray Cartilage of Erie.
Pa.


The election of the Negro mod
orator underlines the militant
role the church's leaders have
taken against racial discrimina-
tion He Is pastor of St. Angus
tin Presbyterian Church In the
Bronx.


The United Presbyterian
Church has almost 3.3 million
members in about 9,l00 churches
in the country, but only minor
fraction are in the southeast
ern states.


The Rev. Hawkins has built
St. Augustine church from nine
members to more than 1000
in his 26 years as its pastor.
The membership includes all
races and services are In sew
eral languages.

EUeYy June thousands of graduates from
grammar school, high school, colleges and
hear endless speeches exhoYting
them to seek the future with more learning.


Graduates from the length and breadth Of
our United States are adnaOnisehed to go for
1VaYd and conquer the world with a diploma
and a fearless heart.


Today in this quickly changing world this
adUice is not sufficient. Graduates from the
eighth grade should be encouraged by great
eY numbers Of private citizens who could
spend a fen dollars to aid some aspiring stu
dent to enter and stay in high school.


There are surely some busiae sSnen IN
Phoenix who could contribute scholarships
to deserving eighth grade and high school
graduates.


Locally, approximately three ha'adred Ne
gro pupils gYad,tate from the Valley elenaem-
toYy schools, less than fifty complete high
school and less than q dozen complete either
the junior college or the university.


Many more opportunities are open to the
younger generation than eveT before. THIS
group of young people aOho graduate must re-
ahze that they are kving in an age when the
sky is their limit. Horizons are aOide and IN
creased employment opportunities are mo1t-
ing.
